lines.text: That's the third sneeze.
I'm afraid you'll have to go to bed.
But I'm not sick. I feel fine!
Oh, Collins, she's perfectly well. A sneeze is nothing to be alarmed at.
Maybe so, But I'm responsible for the child. Come along, dear.

The child sneezes, and you'd think the world has come to an end. Why can't they leave her alone? She's a perfectly normal, healthy child. The way they carried on here, you'd think she was made of glass! Something ought to be done.
How Mr. Barry can stand that woman is beyond me.
You can't expect a widower and a man as busy as Mr. Barry to notice everything that goes on in the house.
Do I have to eat any more of this?
Most definitely. Spinach is very rich in vitamins. I might say disgustingly rich, and very good for you, Miss Barbara.
Why is it so many things you don't like are good for you?
I couldn't say offhand, Miss Barbara, but you must eat some more of your spinach.
Why do I have to?
Well, you see, your lunch calls for so many vitamins, and you must have them.
It seems I can't go anywhere or doing anything with Barry making trouble for me. I hate that man! He causes me more sleepless nights.
Sleepless nights? What does he do, play his trombone under your window or something?

Everything but that. I lay awake half the night thinking up new ideas, and in the morning I find out Barry's not only beaten me to them, he's topped me in a thousand ways. I wish he'd drown in his own soap suds. But I shouldn't be boring you with my troubles.
That's all right. You in this business?
Yes, I'm with the Peck Company. Advertising.
I see. I'm sorry you dislike this fellow Barry, though. He's really not a bad sort.
Oh, you know him?
Slightly. My barber cuts his hair. Perhaps I could bribe him to cut his throat.
Oh, Mr. Barry, do you think she would do?
Let me see. Yes, she'll do very nicely.
Thank you, Mr. Barry. That's just what I thought.
Well, of all the nerve! Letting me talk my head off without even telling me! Just another example of Barry's cleverness, I suppose!
What was she burning about?
I keep her awake nights.
Will you read to me from this?
All right. Which one is it to be?
It's the one where Betsy runs away from the orphan asylum and meets Tony the organ grinder and his monkey.

[reading]
"Betsy Weir was two years old when her mother died. Because the family was poor, Betsy couldn't stay at home, so she was sent to an orphan asylum."
Which was an ugly red brick building far, far away from where Betsy used to live.

Yes, from where Betsy used to live. "Then a young man came dancing around the corner in a green coat and bumped right into her. 'Excuse me,' said the young man. 'I'm always bumping into people. That's why they call me Puddin'-Head.'"
Collins just gets panicky every time the child sneezes.
Collins is right. I want every precaution taken.

Of course I know it's none of my business, Mr. Barry, but did you ever stop to consider that the piling up of precautions and attention was bad for the child? Why she's watched over and pampered and babied to death. If I were you, I'd send Barbara to school where she could be with other children.
Well, there may be something in that. Ring up Collins and tell her I want to speak to her.
I know what Collins will say. Collins always says no. Daddy, why do I always have to play alone? Why can't I play with other children?
Honey, how would you like to go to school?
Oh, goody, goody, goody!
Well, I guess that settles it.
You know, Daddy, this house wouldn't be so lonesome if you'd stay home once in awhile.
If I stayed home all the time, there wouldn't be any house.
Daddy, marry me and let me be your wife!
It's Tony the organ grinder! And his monkey! I know who you are, you're Tony.
Dat's a-right. Antonio's my middle name.
I'm on a vacation. Do you want to come along?
You a very nice-a little bambina. You go home-a to your mama, eh?
I have no mama.
Oh, dat's-a too bad. Den go home-a to your papa. Hey, what's your name-a?
Betsy Weir. I used to live in an orphanage, but they were mean to me, awfully mean, and now I'm on a vacation to see new faces. Your face doesn't look very new.
Well, it's a-good enough for me.
Don't forget, we've got another radio audition tomorrow. You know, this radio racket is a lot harder than Vaudeville used to be. Remember when we got married?
No, and don't remind me. By the way, I'm getting tired of these radio auditions. If we don't land a job soon, I'm going home to my mother.
Well, that's better than bringing the old bat here.
Tony, who is she?
She's an orphan, I tell-a you! She run away, and she a-follow me here.
Jerry, she's a natural. Look at her! Did you ever see a better bet?
Who is she?
She's part of our act, Dolan, Dolan, & Dolan. What's your name?
Betsy Weir. Are you Puddin'-Head?
I'll say he's Puddin'-Head. What's this all about?
That kid's a novelty, just what we need for our new act.
Are you crazy? What do you know about the child?
Everything there is to know. She ran away from an orphan asylum.
Orphan asylum, your aunt. Did you notice her hands? Well, they don't manicure them at an orphan asylum.
I don't know. A buddy of mine got his hair cut in Sing Sing.
Now, listen, sweetheart, remember, you're Bonnie Dolan, the radio star. Don't use your real name around here. Don't even think about it. Just forget that you're Betsy Weir.
Are we playing a game?
That's right. Will you play along with us?
I like games.
Now, don't forget, Betsy.
The name's Bonnie Dolan.

[singing]
My boss Mr. Cupid told me to make hearts loop the loop, never ever to sing about the Good Ship Lollipop or animal crackers in my soup.
Now, Mr. Peck, I understand this place is, well, is going to pot. I'd be willing to, uh, take it off your hands for you. That is, if you'd care to sell.
Do I understand that you - ?
You understand me to say that I'll buy you out. How much?
Do you have the collosal nerve to suggest that I sell my business to you?
Well, why not? You've been losing money for the past two years You're practically broke.
Get out! Get out before I kick you out! Get out!
Why do you want me to go? You're all alone, and I'm not doing anything, either. Tell me a story.
I don't know any stories.
You know, you remind me of old Mr. Spindleshanks. He's the old grouch in the Betsy Weir stories who helps Betsy when she's hungry...
Hungry? You aren't hungry, are you?
No, I just had lunch, and I did something bad, too.
What did you do?
Well, we had spinach, and while Jimmy wasn't looking, I put mine on his plate!
You should've eaten your spinach. It's good for you.
So I've heard.
Where are you going?
I'm going to get along.
Why?
You said for me to.
I never said anything of the sort. All I said was that spinach was good for you.
The Dolans will be on in a few minutes, and if you want to hear a radio show, it'll make yours sound sick!
All right, I'll listen. I'll tell you about it at lunch tomorrow.
Now, remember, my dear, there's going to be a lot of people listening, but you mustn't be nervous, you mustn't be afraid.
Afraid of what?
That's just the thing, my dear, there's nothing to be afraid of.
Do you want me to be afraid?
Heavens no, darling! That's why I'm talking to you.
If I do get afraid, it'll be on account of you talking so much.

[singing on the radio]
An ordinary day becomes a holiday when I'm with you.
It can't be! Her voice is just like Barbara's! If I didn't know my child was at school... I'd swear...
All children's voices sound a lot alike. It's just that slight difference that makes Bonnie stand out. A proud father probably wouldn't even notice that difference.

[on the radio]
Marry me, and let me be your wife!
It is Barbara! I'm telling you, it's Barbara!
Are you losing your mind? That's Bonnie Dolan!
I tell you, it's my daughter!

[on the radio]
Even funny spinach takes like pumpkin pie when I'm with you.
You're just making a complete idiot of yourself. I know the child and I know her parents!
But, I'm her parent!
Listen, darling, tell us the truth. Do you know Mr. Barry?
You won't be angry if I tell you?
No, sweetheart.
Mr. Barry's my daddy!
Didn't I tell you she didn't jump out of a hat? There's only one thing to do. Take her back to the apartment, telephone Barry where she is, and then duck.
Listen, darling, tell us the truth. Do you know Mr. Barry?
You won't be angry if I tell you?
No, sweetheart.
Mr. Barry's my daddy!
Didn't I tell you she didn't jump out of a hat? There's only one thing to do. Take her back to the apartment, telephone Barry where she is, and then duck.
I love a military man!
I love a military man!
I love a military... nurse!
What's your name?
Rufus Washington Jackson Lee.
All by yourself?
Ach, mein gootness!
I sneezed.
Saluti.
Saluti.
But don't I have to go to bed?
What's-a matter? You sleepy?
You eat first.
I like it here!
So small, and so sweet.
Maybe we keep her, yes?
You crazy? What you want to do? You want to go to jail for the kidnap? Five children you have already, six with the monkey.
All right, then I take her to the policemen in the morning.
I've been workin' on a step that's gonna get Bill Robinson talkin' to himself.
Suppose the kid's story does turn out to be a phony? So we believed her. So we fed her, took good care of her, and put her on the air. They can hang you for that, can they?
They can try.
Didn't he like what we did?
Sure he did. I guess he's just going in the next room to applaud.
But you said we were good.
Never pay any attention to what he says.
This client of mine, the one I was telling you about...
Yes?
He wants to see you this afternoon.
We're good!

[singing]
We're good, we're good!
Can you be there at three?
Can we be there at three?
Can we be there at three?
We'll be there at five minutes to three!
Boss or no boss, how about a date for lunch?
Oh, I couldn't possibly...
Oh, be a sport. You're even with me now, aren't you?
I'm ahead of you.
When will it be?
Oh, Friday at one?
Fine, at the Savoy?
Say, Margaret, isn't he one of our competitors?
As far as I'm concerned, he has no competition.
I didn't think I was gonna like you at first, but I like you now.
You do?
Yes, your eyebrows are so nice and ragged.
Do you know to play piggyback?
No, I don't think I do.
Oh, it's easy. Stand up. Now turn around.
Like this?

Now I put my arms around your neck, and you go like this, "Ride a cock to Banbury Cross to see a fine lady upon a white horse. Rings on her fingers and bells on her toes, she shall have music wherever she goes!" You run around and around while you sing it. Take my legs.

[running and singing]
Ride a cockhorse to Banbury Cross, to see a fine lady upon a white horse!
[a man enters his office]
You get out! Can't you see I'm in conference?
[He continues running and singing]
Rings on her fingers and bells on her toes...
Woah!
What?
Do you always tell people to get out?
I do when I'm engaged in important business!
Didn't I tell you all we needed was a break? Thirteen weeks on the dotted line, signed and sealed.
Oh, it's wonderful, Jimmy. I just hope we click.
Oh, we'll knock 'em dead.
Do we have to kill people?
Oh, we won't kill them, we'll just slay 'em.
My goodness, she sneezed! Get a doctor, quick! Maybe we should put her to bed. Maybe we should...
Why don't you just say saluti?
Huh?
How about gesundheit?
Danke schön!
You'll drown in your own soapsuds yet.
I'm afraid I can't afford to drown now. You know, you look very lovely tonight.
Here, have a cocktail. It'll help sustain the illusion.
Why do you have to be so stubborn?
You're the one that's being stubborn. Oh, why do I have to marry a girl like you?
Who said you had to? Who said you're going to? Why, I wouldn't marry you if...
You'll marry me if I want you to.
You know, we're a couple of heels, running out on the kid like this.
I know, but...
Yeah, and a couple of crooks, too.
You're right. Everybody knows Dolan & Dolan, and they know we had the kid.
Yeah, and if we run away, it'll look worse.
Let's go back and face them.
